lines.text: What languages do you speak?
Russian, Polish, Greek, Hungarian, German, Romanian, Bulgar, Serbo-Croat, Romani, Italian, some Arabic, some Yiddish, a little Chinese.
You speak English and Chinese. You never wandered there?
Ah, they come to me, Major, sir. An English woman. A Chinese woman in Latvia. Live with a new woman, learn a new tongue. It's better than Berlitz.
An English woman and you?
Why, I speak English fine. Seven English women.
You're a rolling stone, aren't you? Where do you want to roll to?
You mean, you encourage the men here and the - village women? Why, it's disgusting! It's like animals!
In the country, it's always like that.
If-if the Major finds out what they're doing on his ban on fraternization, I-I-I don't know...
They do not fraternize! No, they do not fraternize! They - just - sleep - together!
The trouble is, you think you run this camp.
No, no, sir. What ever I do, you have the last blame.
Private Amos... Is that a moustache or part of your breakfast?
You'll be staying in the service, of course? It's in the family. People with your background should do pretty well.
Thank you, sir. Emm, I shall be going back to University to study languages. I've been told that they are going to be most important in the new Europe.
Oh, yes. And in the new Army. We could use fellows like you on the staff.
Well, no sir, whatever my father might say, eh, I'm - not really cut out for fighting.
My dear, Pilkington, whoever joined the Army to fight?
Go on! Get out! You bloody gypsy!
